Kentucky asks why not; answer still pending

Louisville Arts Bureau

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 8:45 p.m. EDT October 25, 2014

Kentucky quarterback Patrick Towles throws a pass in the first half against Mississippi State on Saturday(Photo: Mike Weaver)

Tags

  • Southeastern Conference
  • Mark Stoops
  • University of Kentucky
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. – The big black banner was unfurled across two sections, atop hundreds of spectators, and it posed the core question of Mark Stoops' football tenure at the University of Kentucky in the form of a declaration.

"WHY NOT," it said, in large white letters, but the words carried no question mark, and the printer issued no apologies. The strongly worded statement Kentucky issued Saturday afternoon was about pugnacity rather than punctuation; about retracing the forward progress lost last week at LSU.

And if the Wildcats weren't quite ready to muzzle the top-ranked Mississippi State Bulldogs, neither were they inclined to roll over and play dead. Heisman Trophy candidate Dak Prescott ultimately led the visitors to a 45-31 victory, running for two touchdowns and throwing for a third, but Kentucky's big-play capabilities kept it close enough to cause the nation's No. 1 team considerable discomfort.

UK quarterback Patrick Towles completed touchdown passes of 67 yards to Demarco Robinson and 58 yards to Javess Blue and he narrowly missed another long-distance connection when he threw a pass slightly behind freshman Garrett Johnson on a deep route during Kentucky's first possession. He also ran for two touchdowns, the second of them slicing MSU's lead to just seven points with 2:31 remaining.

Kentucky's chance at a resounding upset evaporated on the ensuing onside kick, when Mississippi State's Christian Holmes fielded a bouncing kick and burst through UK's thin formation for a 61-yard touchdown. Only then did the spectators begin departing Commonwealth Stadium in large numbers. Only then was it obvious that UK's big breakthrough would have to wait.

Saturday's game underscored Stoops' need for more depth at the point of attack, With Mississippi State's Josh Robinson carrying 23 times for 198 yards, including a 73-yard touchdown run, the need for more muscle up front was plain. Yet If the Wildcats were overmatched at the line of scrimmage, if they missed too many tackles and whiffed at too many pass rushers, they were consistently challenging on the wings

When the fourth quarter started, Mississippi State's lead stood at 31-24 and ESPN's web site carried an "Upset Alert." When the game ended, the gap between the top of the Southeastern Conference and where Kentucky stands was clear, but maybe not beyond clearing. Stoops' troops are still a recruiting class or two from being able to compete consistently for four quarters with the top teams in college football's best conference, but their days as a doormat are rapidly receding from memory.

Saturday's loss still leaves the 5-3 Wildcats one win from bowl eligibility, and with only one home game remaining on their schedule, but that goal looked a lot more attainable at sundown Saturday than it had a week earlier in Baton Rouge, La.

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE
